metadata.title: Faraday-like Screening by Two-Dimensional Nanomaterials: A Scale-Dependent Tunable Effect

sections.text:
I ncreasing demand for next-generation batteries1 andsupercapacitors2,3 relying on two-dimensional (2D) nanostructured electrodes, and the steady search for efficient 2D nanoscale electronic devices,4 are defining higher accuracy requirements in terms of electric field control. Electrostatic interactions between ions and 2D nanosheets and the screening capabilities of mono- and multilayered 2D materials play a key role in the development of novel electrode concepts aimed at maximizing energy density, life cycle, and charging velocity. At the same time, electric field screening is a major issue in the development of 2D heterostructures for field effect transistors (FETs), where Fermi level and electron band modulation require adequate command of charge densities and applied potentials. In the last years, the response properties of few-layer graphene were investigated by tight binding,5 electrostatic force microscopy, and nonlinear Thomas−Fermi theory,6 largely focusing on uniform in-plane potentials and the resulting internal charge rearrangement. Analogous investigations7 were performed for MoS2, revealing the importance of interlayer coupling in determining the effective in-plane screened potential. Very recently, electric bias measurements were performed to determine charge-density reorganization in multiple 2D van der Waals (vdW) heterostructures,8−10 while asymmetric screening effects were observed11 in MoS2− graphene stacks. Also, experimental evidence12 for complete screening of interface vdW interactions by monolayer graphene coating inspired conspicuous theoretical work,13−15 which confirmed effective opacity to fluctuating dipolar interactions,13 in analogy to a Faraday-like13 cage effect.
While nontrivial response effects have been lately evidenced in two dimensions, Faraday-like electrostatic screening due to 2D nanostructures acting as shielding buffer, for instance, upon ion physisorption,16 is still poorly understood. Faraday screening is a highly versatile technique, routinely adopted at the macroscale for electromagnetic insulation via solid metal cages. However, miniaturization up to the nanometer range is inherently challenged by mechanical stability, chemical reactivity, and fabrication complexity. Adoption of readily available and mechanically and chemically stable 2D materials could thus provide a viable alternative for effective nanoscale electric field control. On the other hand, development of 2D Faraday-like screening techniques demands full characterization of the complex relation between charge density response and total electric field (or resultant physical forces) at arbitrary positionsand far away from the 2D surface. Clearly, the charge response of 2D mono- or multilayered structures to external electric fields is an inherently many-body problem, which involves coupling between electron−nuclear polarizations in low-dimensional topologies. In recent works14,17−20 we demonstrated that both semimetallic π states in graphene, and many-body-coupled localized orbitals in 1D and 2D nanostructures can give rise to ultra nonlocal polarizability. Physically, the strong many-body correlation between single electrons in low dimensions favors coherent charge-response to external electric stimuli, beyond the ∼10

In this Letter we investigate the relation between highly nonlocal many-body polarizability and Faraday-like screening properties of mono- and few-layer 2D structures, at different distance scales. We evidence how the nonlocal response is reflected in major variations of the total (screened) electrostatic field and of its scale dependency as a function of the electronic structure or configuration of the system. The profound variability of screening effects and of their scaling laws with respect to accessible physical parameters opens novel pathways toward experimental regulation and switching of electric fields, facilitating the design of ionic interactions in 2D nanostructured electrodes and inhomogeneous electric fields in FETs. The electric field induced by an external point-like charge is computed throughout the Letter according to the geometry illustrated in Figure 1. The external charge is placed at Rc at
fixed distance zc from the surface, while the total electric field is measured at the position Rf at distance zf below the same surface to assess the net screening effect of the 2D structure. The total electric potential, vtot, in Rf can be obtained as the sum of the bare (external) Coulomb interaction vC and a screening (or polarization) term, which is generated by the charge displacement induced by the external field on the material. As evidenced in our previous work,17,20 a full many-body treatment of the interacting response is mandatory for capturing detailed nonlocality features and correct screened interaction scaling. MoS2. We begin our analysis considering mono- and multilayer MoS2. The presence of a 1.8 eV direct band gap 21 ensures locality of the electronic orbitals,22 so that an atomistic approach to the bare dipolar response can be applied, according to the recently proposed self-consistent screening (SCS)23,24 method. Within SCS, the electronic response of each atom is mapped onto a single quantum harmonic oscillator (QHO) in a way to exactly reproduce static polarizabilities and homoatomic C6 Hamaker constants. Given the interest in long-range distances, the dipole limit to the Coulomb interaction is taken, while its short-range tail is naturally damped because of the overlap between atomic charge densities.23−25 By assuming Gaussian electronic distribution coherently with the QHO approach, one finds that the short-range damped Coulomb interaction between atoms i and j at relative distance r is vD(r) = erf(r/σij)/r, where σ σ σ= +ij i 2 j 2 and σ π α= ( 2/ /3)ii 0 1/3 (αi 0 being the ith

Because of the inclusion of many-body terms up to infinite order, the C6 Hamaker constants obtained by frequency integration of SCS screened polarizabilities were shown to match within 6.3% with reference time-dependent density functional theory (TDDFT) data over a 1225 molecular dimers database.23 SCS accuracy within 8% was also found for large atomic clusters, compared to TDDFT, whereas deviations up to ∼70% were found by integration of bare polarizabilities (neglecting RPA many-body effects). Repeated indices in the above formula and hereafter are to be regarded as contracted. We stress that atomic summation occurs over the whole MoS2 2D crystal, while no periodic replicas of the charge are to be included. Because of the

periodicity of the MoS2 lattice, substantial computational speedup is accomplished by convenient reciprocal space implementation of eqs 3 and 4 (see the Supporting Information), which will be consistently adopted in the present calculations. Also, in order to quantitatively estimate screening effects, we define an effective screening ratio ϵ (not to be confused with the nonlocal dielectric function of the materials), computed as ϵ−1 = Etot/Eext at Rf (see Figure 1). From Figure 2 we observe that the total electric field in Rf is effectively reduced by the MoS2 sheets, through a variable
effective screening ratio. By focusing for instance on monolayer MoS2 we find that ϵ
−1 gradually increases as a function of zf. Moreover, if Rf and Rc are aligned (i.e., they differ only by the z component), the direction of the total electric field is consistently parallel to the z axis. The same is true also for MoS2 bi- and trilayer samples, where negligible x, y electric field components are found, because of crystal symmetry. Many-body effects play a crucial role in screening; in fact, a naive model of noninteracting QHOs (i.e., with local polarizability only) could not capture the correct screening nor predict its variability with respect to zf. In fact (see the Supporting Information), the 2D independent QHOs model predicts the screening field to be aligned to the bare component, thereby enhancing the total field. We also note that a continuum 2D model with homogeneous local polarizability predicts absence of screening, thus it is inapplicable to the present context. In low-dimensional systems, both modulus and space dependence of the screening electric field are critically17,20 influenced by the strength and momentum dependence of the interacting (many-body) response function. More specifically, the many-body coupling is known to alter the overall polarizability of the material,24 while the dispersion of collective polarization modes determines momentum dependence14,17,20,26 and consequent nonlocality of the dipolar response. Considering again the noninteracting QHO model, characterized by local polarizability (q-independent Fourier transform), we find that the screening field decays much faster than Eext with respect to zf (see the Supporting Information),
yielding unitary ϵ−1 already at the ∼10 Å scale, so that total f ield enhancement is found only at short zf. Hence, the relatively slow variation of ϵ−1 with respect to distance observed in Figure 2 can be directly related to the expected nonlocality20 of the MoS2 polarizability; in fact, the Coulomb coupling in 2D is known to induce ultralong-ranged electron correlation,17,20 enabling finite dipolar response at large distance from the incoming perturbation. On the other hand, given the presence of a finite band gap, the dipolar response range of MoS2 cannot be infinite, so that one expects that ϵ −1 will eventually approach 1 for zf → ∞. While the current study relies on ideal periodic crystals, under realistic experimental conditions 2D materials can undergo adsorption of chemical moieties from the environment or exhibit buckling, strain, etc. Although these features could partly alter the response properties of the 2D crystals, the latest experimental techniques,27 such as chemical vapor deposition on suitable substrates (with consequent highquality flakes production), programmed desorption, or vacuum chambers, can now be exploited in order to control or minimize deviation from ideal conditions. Nonetheless, it could be useful to estimate, for instance, the actual effect of strain on overall screening. To address this issue we impose 2D isotropic expansion in MoS2, recomputing ϵ
−1(zf) for the monolayer system (see the Supporting Information). We find that by successively imposing 2.5% and 5% lattice constant increase, ϵ−1 consistently grows at all zf values, compatible with a moderate decrease of the screening. The qualitative picture is therefore preserved, while the weaker screening can be interpreted in terms of overall polarizability density (polarizability per unit surface area) reduction and consequent screening term decrease. Concerning buckling, one could reasonably expect that measurable effects should emerge when zf is of the same order as the lateral (in-plane) diameter of the deformation. However, buckling is most often characterized by small deformations d along the z direction (d ≪ zf), so that the overall screening contribution is again expected to be moderate. Adsorption at very low coverage (if preserving the MoS2 band gap) will also introduce only local variations to the overall density response, so that once more minor impact on the total field is expected. By switching from MoS2 monolayer to multilayer, we consistently observe a reduction of ϵ−1. The trend is consistent with an overall enhancement of the screening field, which can be interpreted in terms of effective polarizability increase caused by the additional layers. Finally, we analyze the variability of the electric field with respect to planar coordinates (by varying Rf parallel to the surface at fixed zf). In Figure 2 (inset) we observe that the electric field tends to decrease in the lateral directions, exhibiting small oscillations at finite lateral distance, in qualitative agreement with Friedel’s theory. Given the q-independence of ϵπ, both the total electrostatic potential in real space and the total electric field will be subject to the same constant screening (constant screening ratio). By adopting the estimate29 vF ≈ 0.5 au for the bare Fermi velocity, one finds ϵπ
−1 ≈ 0.24. On the other hand, both theoretical19,30,31 and experimental32 work have lately suggested renormalization of the Fermi velocity at low momenta. According to a strong power-law correction for vF, derived from a two-loop level renormalization group approach,31 one finds a slight variability of the ϵπ −1 screening constant with respect to zf (see the Supporting Information). Although the exact form of the renormalized vF at low momenta is still unknown (due to the complexity of the full many body problem and limited experimental resolution in cyclotron mass measurements32), according to our analysis π electrons in MLG can be reasonably expected to damp electrostatic fields by ∼60−75% for zf in the range up to ∼100 Å. In addition, we also stress that the measurement of electric field screening by monolayer graphene could provide straightforward experimental access to the renormalized Fermi velocity, favoring direct investigation of the low q range (corresponding to large zf). We also note that, because of proportionality between polarizability and density response, a constant (q-independent) bare polarizability enhancement should be reflected into a constant multiplicative factor C > 1 for χ̃π
0, namely, −Cq/4vF at zero frequency (corresponding to vF renormalization by C
−1). Consequently, one finds ϵπ −1 = (1 + πC/2vF) −1, which corresponds to an overall screening enhancement. This result is indeed rather general, and because of the common underlying RPA formulation, it extends also to the discrete SCS model. Even in finite-gap 2D layers we thus expect to find enhanced screening upon increase of the polarizability density. The screening effect of multilayer graphene, on the other hand, is less trivial to infer34,35 and necessitates computation of the full RPA interacting response, where all layers are coupled to each other. Moreover, it is well-known from the tightbinding approximation that the Coulomb coupling between adjacent layers can modify the Dirac cone band structure36,37 when many layers are stacked together. Although within the current approach to χ̃π
0 we cannot distinguish between A and B triangular sublattices, we still expect the MLG π-electron bare response to be a good starting point for including interlayer interactions within the RPA approach, especially for A−A stacking. We also note that, despite the constant effective screening ratio of MLG, the overall screening effect due to successive layers can be straightforwardly computed neither by exponentiation nor by linear rescaling of the MLG inverse screening ratio. In fact, from Figure 3 (inset) we observe that while the actual RPA effective ϵπ
−1 exhibits evident nonlinearity, its dependence on the number of layers substantially deviates from naive sequential multiplication of single-layer inverse screening ratios: (ϵML)

We finally observe that, although delocalized π orbitals are expected to provide dominant screening contributions at large zf, σ electrons can also be sensitive to external fields. In analogy to MoS2, we thus effectively include many-body polarization effects by mapping the bare polarizability of σ electrons into a set of coupled QHOs. The distinction between σ and π orbitals is accomplished by means of Maximally localized Wannier functions (MLWFs), according to our previous work.38 MLWFs are obtained via unitary transformation of the Kohn−Sham orbitals (obtained here using the Perdew− Burke−Ernzerhof exchange−correlation functional39 via the FHI-Aims40 and Quantum Espresso packages41), by minimizing the spread functional22,42,43 Ω, which provides a direct measurement of the electronic orbitals effective width. After computing the MLWFs relative to a MLG unit cell, we discriminate π and σ electrons, identifying π states as those with largest spread (i.e., beyond ∼2.5 Bohr2), while the static polarizabilities and oscillator frequencies are computed from the MLWFs spread, according to the Drude model.38 In order to effectively account for the contextual presence of π electrons, the interoscillator coupling is screened via the constant screening ratio ϵπ previously computed. In first-order approximation, the total electric field in Rf can finally be computed as the sum of the previously derived π-screened field, plus the screening electric field induced by polarization of σ electrons. Although our approach does not fully account for σ−π interactions, our calculations suggest that σ electrons should not significantly alter the above picture (see Figure 3). We also note that χ̃π
0 was derived assuming linear Dirac-cone dispersion of single electron orbitals up to infinite energy. However, at low zf, corrections due to Dirac cone f initeness 44 may also contribute the overall screening, causing slight deviation from the constant screening factor. In passing, we further remark that both semilocal density functional theory14 and the recent linear response theory (LRT)45 may also be suitable to treat electrostatic screening of 2D-layered systems (natively including electronic hybridization and band structure modification), under the condition that highly dense k-point sampling of the Brillouin zone is adopted. Although semilocal DFT approximations provide a poor description of long-range correlation contributions, DFT response to external fields automatically includes many body terms at (and beyond) the RPA level;46 because of DFT self-consistency, external perturbations do not only act as an external potential energy term but further propagate into the Hartree and exchange− correlation contributions. As a consequence, the density response function satisfies a Dyson-like self-consistent equation, compatibly with the required many-body formulation.
Comparison with 2D Electron Gas. To complete our discussion, we compare previous results for gapped MoS2 and quasi-metallic graphene with the ideal case of a 2D electron gas (characterized by parabolic single-particle level dispersion in k). Because of intralayer Coulomb coupling, the RPA interacting response exactly compensates the 2π/q factor in the charge-layer electrostatic potential, while the product of the exponential terms (as from eq 8) equals the exponential factor in the external field. Faraday-cage screening hence shares many-body origin too and is absent in the independent-particle model, given that limq→0χ̃EG

Conversely, when zf is comparable to or smaller than the 1/kF length scale, according to RPA the 2D electron gas cannot fully screen the electrostatic field; in fact, Ẽtot(q) coincides with Ẽext(q) for q→ ∞. Overall, the 2D electron gas provides stronger screening with respect to both graphene and MoS2 at relevant zf ranges (see Figure 3). We note, though, that low-q components of the Fourier transformed electric field are better screened by graphene, because of the linearity of χ̃G(q) in q. In contrast, finite-gap MoS2, provides strong short-range screening, which gradually vanishes at growing distance zf. We finally remark that, in the special case of n-doped AB-stacked graphene bilayer, the existence of partially filled parabolic bands (caused by distortion of the Dirac cone) suggests metal-like screening in the long-range limit. In conclusion, our analysis of Faraday-like electrostatic screening by 2D materials reveals rich variability of the screening and total fields in terms of accessible physical parameters, including band structure and density response nonlocality, strain, polarizability, and number of layers. Remarkably, the effective electrostatic field screening ratio emerges as an inherently many-body feature, whose scaling in terms of the surface distance zf is ultimately determined by band structure and dipolar response nonlocality. While ideal 2D metallic systems (modeled as a 2D electron gas) cause complete electrostatic screening in the long-range limit (Faraday cage effect) where intralayer many-body Coulomb coupling dominates the density response, quasi-metallic graphene exhibits a finite, yet roughly distance-independent, screening ratio. In contrast, finite-gap MoS2 2D layers produce marked distance dependence of the screening facto, because of the intrinsic finiteness of the charge-response length scale. The remarkable versatility of Faraday-like electrostatic screening in terms of the aforementioned parameters, and as a function of the surface distance, opens viable pathways for detailed experimental control of electric fields at the nanoscale via readily available and mechanically and chemically stable 2D nanomaterials. Suitably designed 2D nanostructures could accordingly provide valuable means for nanoscale electric field control in
DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpclett.9b00860 J. Phys. Chem. Lett. 2019, 10, 2044−2050
2048
potentially countless fields, including (i) ultimate supercapacitor electrodes (increasingly based on 2D nanomaterials2,3), where charge accumulation is directly related to electrostatics, whereas overly intense electric fields can provide a challenge for available electrolytes; (ii) field-effect transistors or Schottky junctions based on 2D nanomaterials,4,49,50 where electric field tuning is largely exploited for Fermi level, band structure, and band alignment; (iii) ultrathin cable51 shielding, where transmission of clean electromagnetic signals at the nanoscale is strongly favored by adequate control of external disturbance; etc. Recently, 2D materials were also experimentally proposed12 as opaque shields for the screening of interface vdW interactions due to bulky substrates. In analogy with dispersion, we thus expect that 2D materials could shield the large induced polarization occurring in bulk-like substrates, thereby enabling control of effective substrate−adsorbate interactions, with obvious benefits for surface science and, possibly, catalysis. Electrostatic screening in quasi-2D lipidic membranes52,53 may also play a fundamental role in the functioning of cells, enabling effective shielding of the intracellular area from ionic electric fields characterizing the external medium. Additional extensions of the present theory to curved geometries may also include controlled shielding of electric fields generated by ionic and polar molecules via fullerenes, finite-gap and metallic nanotubes, or 2D-derived porous nanostructures. In fact, carbon nanotubes have recently been proposed54,55 as an effective means for selective drug delivery, where the shielding of intermolecular interactions has emerged as a valuable pathway for controlling biomolecules’ activity and molecular recognition processes. Finally, the close relation found between charge response nonlocality and electrostatic screening implies that accurate electric field measurement could be exploited in order to infer the actual charge-density response range in 2D materials, and vice versa. Of particular interest is also the possibility (see the Supporting Information for further discussion) to extract direct information about thestill largely debatedFermi velocity, vF, renormalization occurring in graphene in the challenging low-momentum regime by measuring screened fields at large zf and exploiting direct dependence of Faraday-like screening on vF.

metadata.abstractText: The modulation of electric fields by monoor few-layer twodimensional (2D) nanomaterials embodies a major challenge through vast technological areas, including 2D nanoscale electronics, ultrathin cable shielding, and nanostructured battery and supercapacitor electrodes. By a quantum-mechanical analysis of Faraday-like electrostatic screening due to diverse 2D nanolayers we demonstrate that electric field screening is triggered by charge response nonlocality. The effective screening factor is not only influenced by average polarizability but further exhibits nontrivial scalings with respect to surface distance: while ideal 2D metallic systems cause complete Faraday-cage screening, semimetallic graphene yields a finite, roughly scale-independent field reduction factor. Conversely, screening by finite-gap MoS2 appears most effective in the vicinity of the surfaces, gradually vanishing in the long-distance limit because of the intrinsic finiteness of the charge-response length scale. The variability of screening effects and of their scaling laws with respect to accessible physical parameters opens novel pathways for experimental modulation of electric fields, ionic interactions, and adsorption of charged or polar moieties. I ncreasing demand for next-generation batteries and supercapacitors relying on two-dimensional (2D) nanostructured electrodes, and the steady search for efficient 2D nanoscale electronic devices, are defining higher accuracy requirements in terms of electric field control. Electrostatic interactions between ions and 2D nanosheets and the screening capabilities of monoand multilayered 2D materials play a key role in the development of novel electrode concepts aimed at maximizing energy density, life cycle, and charging velocity. At the same time, electric field screening is a major issue in the development of 2D heterostructures for field effect transistors (FETs), where Fermi level and electron band modulation require adequate command of charge densities and applied potentials. In the last years, the response properties of few-layer graphene were investigated by tight binding, electrostatic force microscopy, and nonlinear Thomas−Fermi theory, largely focusing on uniform in-plane potentials and the resulting internal charge rearrangement. Analogous investigations were performed for MoS2, revealing the importance of interlayer coupling in determining the effective in-plane screened potential. Very recently, electric bias measurements were performed to determine charge-density reorganization in multiple 2D van der Waals (vdW) heterostructures, while asymmetric screening effects were observed in MoS2− graphene stacks. Also, experimental evidence for complete screening of interface vdW interactions by monolayer graphene coating inspired conspicuous theoretical work, which confirmed effective opacity to fluctuating dipolar interactions, in analogy to a Faraday-like cage effect. While nontrivial response effects have been lately evidenced in two dimensions, Faraday-like electrostatic screening due to 2D nanostructures acting as shielding buffer, for instance, upon ion physisorption, is still poorly understood. Faraday screening is a highly versatile technique, routinely adopted at the macroscale for electromagnetic insulation via solid metal cages. However, miniaturization up to the nanometer range is inherently challenged by mechanical stability, chemical reactivity, and fabrication complexity. Adoption of readily available and mechanically and chemically stable 2D materials could thus provide a viable alternative for effective nanoscale electric field control. On the other hand, development of 2D Faraday-like screening techniques demands full characterization of the complex relation between charge density response and total electric field (or resultant physical forces) at arbitrary positionsand far away from the 2D surface. Clearly, the charge response of 2D monoor multilayered structures to external electric fields is an inherently many-body problem, which involves coupling between electron−nuclear polarizations in low-dimensional topologies. In recent works we demonstrated that both semimetallic π states in graphene, and many-body-coupled localized orbitals in 1D and 2D nanostructures can give rise to ultra nonlocal polarizability. In this Letter we investigate the relation between highly nonlocal many-body polarizability and Faraday-like screening properties of monoand few-layer 2D structures, at different distance scales. We evidence how the nonlocal response is reflected in major variations of the total (screened) electrostatic field and of its scale dependency as a function of the electronic structure or configuration of the system. The profound variability of screening effects and of their scaling laws with respect to accessible physical parameters opens novel pathways toward experimental regulation and switching of electric fields, facilitating the design of ionic interactions in 2D nanostructured electrodes and inhomogeneous electric fields in FETs. The electric field induced by an external point-like charge is computed throughout the Letter according to the geometry illustrated in Figure 1. The external charge is placed at Rc at fixed distance zc from the surface, while the total electric field is measured at the position Rf at distance zf below the same surface to assess the net screening effect of the 2D structure. The total electric potential, vtot, in Rf can be obtained as the sum of the bare (external) Coulomb interaction vC and a screening (or polarization) term, which is generated by the charge displacement induced by the external field on the material.
